tossups.question: A violin concerto by a composer from this country begins with a cadenza followed by six studies, a coda, and an adagio for 22 soloists. Leonard Slatkin premiered an unfinished seven-movement tone poem by that composer from this country that was inspired by the Popul Vuh. Another composer from this country was inspired by the death of his father to compose the piece (*) Adiós Nonino. That composer, who was also a prolific player of the bandoneon, helped popularize the nuevo form of a traditional dance from this country, which was home to composer Alberto Ginastera. Astor Piazzolla is from, for 10 points, what South American country which, along with its neighbor Uruguay, created the tango?
tossups.answer: Argentina

tossups.question: John Collingwood Bruce's 19th century handbook for visiting this tourist attraction is now in its 14th edition. A skillet called the Ilam Pan bears the names of four parts of this tourist attraction. Contemporary tourists visiting this site often stop by an Army Museum next to Vindolanda, a place where many tablets have been found. One part of this larger site, Milecastle 42, shows evidence of the (*) Vallum, a ditch just to the south of it. In the 17th century, John Speed published maps of this site, which he named for the Picts. This site is south of a similar one named for Antonine. This structure is most commonly named for the emperor who succeeded Trajan. For 10 points, name this defensive structure in modern-day Britain.
tossups.answer: Hadrian's Wall [or Vallum Aelium; or Roman Wall; or Vallum Hadriani; accept Pict's Wall before Pict is mentioned]

tossups.question: A term called perezhivanie ("PEZ-er-sha-VAHN-ee") was a key component of one system for this discipline and is contrasted with the "reality of doing" that's part of Sanford Meisner's technique for it. Another technique for this discipline focuses on "objectives," "obstacles," and "intentions." Extensive preparation was a hallmark of Stella Adler's school for this discipline. A long-running James Lipton interview series gets (*) "inside" the head of people in this discipline. Asking questions such as "Who Am I? and "What Do I Want?" are common exercises when following a system for this discipline developed by Konstantin Stanislavski called The Method which is often used to "get into character." For 10 points, name this discipline practiced on screen by Marlon Brando.
tossups.answer: acting [accept method acting; accept answers like being a movie star or stage star or playing a role; prompt on film or theater or movies]

tossups.question: A "Statement from the Heart" by these people's Makarrata Commission has called for a repeal of Section 25's race-based disqualifications for voting. Until 2022, WAM Clothing held the copyright on a black and red flag of these people with a yellow disc in the center. In 2020, Jean-Sebastien Jacques was forced out of Rio Tinto after his company destroyed a (*) 46,000-year-old site sacred to these people. One of these people named Bruce Trevorrow sued for reparations over a family separation policy. In 2008, these people were issued a National Apology to the Stolen Generations from Kevin Rudd. In 2017, these people held a National Constitutional Convention at Uluru. For 10 points, name these indigenous people of Australia.
tossups.answer: Aboriginal Australians [accept Torres Strait Islander peoples; accept answers like indigenous peoples of Australia or native peoples of Australia before the end; prompt on Australians]

tossups.question: A constant named for a scientist with this surname, which varies with "J times J plus one," appears in a law named for that scientist which can be found by approximating the Brillouin ("BREE-yoo-ahn") function. A scientist with this surname, the first namesake of a law describing the magnetic susceptibility in the paramagnetic region, also names a law by which some materials' (*) magnetization varies inversely with temperature. That scientist with this surname names a temperature above which materials lose their ferromagnetism. Two scientists with this surname built on the work of Henri Becquerel ("BECK-uh-rell") by isolating polonium and radium. For 10 points, give this surname shared by the scientists who named radioactivity, Pierre and Marie.
tossups.answer: Curie [accept Marie Curie or Pierre Curie; accept Maria Salomea Skłodowska] (The second sentence describes the Curie-Weiss law)

tossups.question: This conflict's "unthinkable" nature is analyzed in the third chapter of Michel-Rolph Trouillot's Silencing the Past. A man noted for his brutality in carrying out the order "cut off their heads and burn their houses" following this conflict lends his name to a type of undead figure. A civil war that took place during this larger conflict, the War of the Knives, ended with Andre (*) Rigaud being exiled. The British sent Thomas Maitland to help Charles Leclerc during this conflict, though they both quickly retreated due to a yellow fever epidemic. Following this conflict, a controversial order to kill white people was given by JeanJacques Dessalines. For 10 points, what slave revolt established an independent country in the Caribbean?
tossups.answer: Haitian Revolution [or Révolution Haïtienne; accept Haitian War of Independence] (The second clue refers to Jean Zombi.)

tossups.question: A parody of this work, which states that "one thing at least is certain, light has weight," was written after Arthur Eddington's expedition to Principe ("prin-SEE-pay"). This work was popularized after a onepenny clearance copy of it was discovered by Dante Gabriel Rossetti. This work is referenced in the title of a play about the Miller family's Fourth of July, the only major comedy by Eugene O'Neill. The words "tamam shud" appear in this work, in which two vessels ponder "Who is the (*) potter, pray, and who the pot?" Edward FitzGerald's idiosyncratic translation of this poetic work describes how "Wilderness were Paradise enow" due to "A Jug of Wine, a Loaf of Bread—and Thou." For 10 points, name this collection of quatrains attributed to Omar Khayyam.
tossups.answer: The Rubáiyát ("ROO-bye-at") of Omar Khayyám

tossups.question: In chapter 2 of this man’s namesake book, this man calls his present location "Sheol," ("SHEE-ohl") the Hebrew realm of the dead. In Luke 11, when the Pharisees demand a miraculous sign, Jesus says that he will only give the sign of this man. Jesus also calls himself greater than this man, to whom God talks about a city's inhabitants who "cannot tell their right hand from their left." After initially boarding a ship from Joppa, this man (*) turns around and goes to Nineveh. While asleep, this man is chosen via casting lots and volunteers to be thrown overboard. Christian theologians consider that Jesus's three days in the grave were foreshadowed by, for 10 points, which Old Testament prophet's three days in the belly of a fish?
tossups.answer: Jonah [or Jonas]

tossups.question: Description acceptable. An "air of the dream" is said to cling to this place, whose original design was the interior of a giant skull. One character fantasizes about hanging a hammock between the "two beautiful elm trees" that used to stand outside this location, which is now surrounded by high-rise apartments. That character worries he doesn't "have a thing in the ground" before planting a garden outside of this building in the middle of the night. This building is frequented by (*) Bernard, who visits to help a star football player with his math homework. Linda bemoans that she made the last payment on this property during the funeral of her husband, who crashed his car for the insurance money. For 10 points, name this residence of Willy Loman in an Arthur Miller play.
tossups.answer: the house from Death of a Salesman [accept Willy Loman's house or any answer that indicates the place where the Lomans live; accept the set of Death of a Salesman; prompt on Brooklyn or New York]

tossups.question: Ristocetin's ability to induce this process is used to differentiate between conditions that impact this process. Schisto·cytes form in extremely dangerous occurrences of this process, which include D·I·C. Breakdown of this process' products forms F·D·Ps such as D-dimers. Degranulation during this process releases ADP, calcium, and serotonin, which occurs after the binding of GpIB-IX-V ("G-P-one-B-nine-five") to a sub·endo·the·lial glycoprotein. Factor Xa ("Ten-A") is produced from both the (*) extrinsic and intrinsic pathways in the protease cascade driven secondary portion of this process, which in turn occurs after the formation of a fibrin-containing plug. Hemophilia occurs due to the inability to properly undergo, for 10 points, what platelet-driven process?
tossups.answer: blood clotting [or coagulation or hemostasis; accept platelet agglutination]

tossups.question: One of these policies in New Zealand popularized the term "Hokonui" and was voted on every three years between 1911 and 1987. Russia adopted one of these policies after the death of Prince Oleg in 1914, cutting off taxes from the kabak system. A limited form of this policy popular in Scandinavia was piloted in Gothenburg, Sweden and gave a monopoly to a public trust. An American society named for this policy had the motto "Do Everything" and was led by feminist (*) Frances Willard. Germany's Junker ("YUN-kers") class generally opposed this policy since it ate into their monopoly on schnapps. A federal law enforcing this policy was sponsored by Andrew Volstead and was opposed by the "wets." For 10 points, name this policy enacted in the US via the 18th Amendment.
tossups.answer: prohibition of alcohol [or temperance; accept answers like regulating the sale of alcohol]

tossups.question: This scholar's daughter wrote about how women were forced to treat "life as an improvisatory art" in the 1989 book Composing a Life. During World War II, this scholar led the Committee on Food Habits at the National Research Council and wrote the pro-British book And Keep Your Powder Dry. Jessie Bernard criticized this scholar's generalizations about the feminine nature of the (*) Arapesh. This parent of Mary Catherine Bateson ended one book with a call for Americans to "permit their children to see adult human bodies" like the children on the island of Ta'u. Derek Freeman challenged the conclusions of this student of Franz Boas regarding the sexuality of the young girls she studied. For 10 points, name this anthropologist who wrote Coming of Age in Samoa.
tossups.answer: Margaret Mead [accept Gregory Bateson on the first sentence because that clue also applies to him]

tossups.question: In a poem by this author, the "hardness and the brightness and the plain" and the "far-reaching singleness" of the moon reminds the speaker of "the strength and the pain / of being young." That poem by this author takes its title from a line in "Sonnet 31" by Philip Sidney. The speaker stands "plain as a wardrobe" as dawn arrives and postmen begin to go "from house to house" in a late-period poem by this author that opens, "I work (*) all day, and get half-drunk at night." Another poem by this author of "Sad Steps" describes a period "between the end of the Chatterley ban / And the Beatles' first LP." The speaker advises, "Don't have any kids yourself" in a poem by, for 10 points, what British poet of "Annus Mirabilis" and "This Be the Verse?"
tossups.answer: Philip Larkin

tossups.question: A region which resembles these features is formed by rear flank downdrafts and may choke off the inflow to a mesocyclone. Baroclinic instability in the mid-latitudes produces these features west of cyclonic lows, explaining why they typically approach from the poles. A sudden increase in pressure and worsening of weather accompanies the passage of these features. Rainbands accompany the lows that form ahead of these features, which can form (*) squall lines in unstable conditions. As these features catch their slower counterparts, a trough ("troff") of lower density air is forced up in a process termed "occlusion." For 10 points, name these wedges of dense air characterized by a line of blue triangles on a weather map and by low temperatures.
tossups.answer: cold fronts [accept pseudocold fronts; accept squall lines before mentioned; prompt on gust fronts]

tossups.question: A 2010 proposal to reduce the amount of TV shows broadcast in this language on GZBN sparked widespread protests. Speakers of this language often use an orchid called a bauhinia ("bau-HEE-nee-uha") as a symbol. The "heroic bloodshed" movie A Better Tomorrow was recorded in this language by the director of Mission: Impossible 2. Slapstick action films such as Drunken Master were originally recorded in this language. This language was the most widely spoken of the (*) fangyan targeted in a 1930s suppression campaign. This non-English language is often used by protestors opposing encroachment into the One Country, Two Systems policy adopted after a British handover in 1997. For 10 points, name this language widely spoken in Hong Kong that is unintelligible with Mandarin.
tossups.answer: Cantonese [accept Canton Language or Guangzhou Language; accept Yue speech; prompt on Chinese; do not accept or prompt on "Mandarin"]

tossups.question: The Metternich Stela records a story in which this goddess was defended by a group of seven creatures led by Tefen. Drawing on Plutarch's description of a statue of this goddess in Sais, many Enlightenment writers used this goddess' "veil" as a symbol of the mysteries of nature. In the Roman world, this goddess was the subject of a (*) mystery religion that Lucius joins in The Golden Ass. This goddess obtained Ra's secret name by using her skill in magic to cure him of a snakebite. With help from her sister Nephthys, this goddess gathered the forty-two dismembered body parts of her husband and revived him. For 10 points, name this Egyptian mother goddess, the wife and sister of Osiris.
tossups.answer: Isis

tossups.question: A recent exhibit on this art movement "Beyond Borders" includes Koga Harue's The Sea. At the first UK exhibit of this art movement, one artist almost suffocated in a diving suit. A leader of this movement participated in several collaborative exquisite corpse drawings. A 2022 Met exhibit titled for this movement featured Eine Kleine Nachtmusik by Dorothea Tanning and a painting where a hand grabs a breast connected to a leg titled (*) Soft Construction with Boiled Beans. Sculptures from this movement include a sofa modeled after Mae West's lips and the Lobster Telephone by an artist who painted ants crawling on an orange clock. For 10 points, name this art movement exemplified by The Persistence of Memory by Salvador Dali.
tossups.answer: International Surrealism

tossups.question: This politician vowed to "kick the hell out of" Garry Trudeau because he was always depicted as invisible in Doonesbury. After visiting a Florida grocers convention, this politician was mocked for being unable to use a barcode scanner. Lee Atwater engineered a campaign ad for this politician which vilified his opponent's stance on "weekend prison passes" and showed a (*) mugshot of an African-American criminal. This politician lost voter support after he reneged on his promise of "Read my lips: no new taxes." This politician, who ran the "Willie Horton" ad, had earlier debated Geraldine Ferraro in the 1984 vice presidential debates. For 10 points, name this politician who defeated Michael Dukakis to become the 41st President of the U.S.
tossups.answer: George H. W. Bush [or George Herbert Walker Bush; accept answer like the elder George Bush or the senior George Bush; accept Bush 41 until "41st" is mentioned; prompt on George Bush; do not accept or prompt on "W. Bush", "Walker Bush", or "George W. Bush"]

tossups.question: The amino acid changes made to insulin glargine ("GLAHR-jeen") increase its half-life by changing this quantity from insulin's value of zero. A high net value of this quantity is possessed by most intrinsically disordered proteins, which thus avoid an entropically favorable effect that encourages folding. Adding SDS to proteins linearizes them and normalizes this quantity per unit mass. This value equals zero at the (*) iso·electric point. The net value of this quantity for a protein at biological pH is found by counting the number of acidic and basic amino acid residues, which possess this property due to protonation or deprotonation. Running a gel separates compounds by size and, for 10 points, what property, which allows them to undergo electro·pho·resis?
tossups.answer: electric charge

tossups.question: In this novel, the trend of memorizing digits of pi is obsessed over by the lawyer Paravant. In this novel, a character whose grandfather was a carbonaro always calls the protagonist "my dear engineer." After seven months, this novel's protagonist attends a debauched Walpurgis Night party with a Russian woman who eventually goes out with the Javanese coffee magnate (*) Peeperkorn. In this novel, the Jesuit Naphta ("NAFF-tah") has many debates with the Italian humanist Settembrini. Though intending to stay only three weeks, this novel's protagonist ends up spending seven years in the title location, where his cousin Joachim ("YO-ah-kim") dies of tuberculosis. Hans Castorp lives in a Swiss sanatorium in, for 10 points, what novel by Thomas Mann?
tossups.answer: The Magic Mountain [or Der Zauberberg]

tossups.question: Upon this country's 1956 independence, the Umma Party took control, though it would later be forced to go underground following Gaafar Nimeiri's coup. People from this country who were relocated from Kakuma refugee camp to the United States were known as its "Lost Boys." During a 1993 famine in this country, Kevin Carter took a photograph showing a vulture staring at an emaciated child. After Mohamed (*) "Hemeti" Dagalo led a military coup in this country in 2019, he refused to extradite a former leader to the ICC. Baggara and Abbala herders, who are minorities in this country, were targeted by the Janjaweed militia during the Darfur genocide. For 10 points, name this African country whose dictator Omar alBashir led from Khartoum.
tossups.answer: Republic of the Sudan [do not prompt on or accept "South Sudan"]

bonuses.leadin: At age 81, one author published a 2012 memoir of this war titled There Was a Country. For 10 points each:
answers: rivers [accept A Bend in the River]
parts: Name this war. Jonathan repeats that "nothing puzzles God" despite his "egg rasher" being stolen in a story set after this war, titled "Civil Peace."
There Was a Country and "Civil Peace" are works about the Biafran War by this author, who described how Okonkwo disrupts the "Week of Peace" in Things Fall Apart.

Christopher Okigbo, an author who died in the Biafran War, personified one of these things as "Mother Idoto" in the collection Heavensgate. In a V. S. Naipaul ("NYE-paul") novel whose title ends with this word, Salim lives under the regime of the Big Man.

bonuses.leadin: The first bicycle to ever win a race was also the first to use these components. For 10 points each:
answers: bearings [accept plain bearings or ball bearings or rolling(-element) bearings]
rolling without sliding [accept rolling resistance or rolling friction]
parts: Name these components which are defined by limiting movement to a single mode. Plain examples of these components are just holes for an axle, but better known varieties have races that constrain other moving elements.
A bike moves because its wheels undergo this form of motion, a combination of rotation and translating. Resistance to this form of motion is due to deformation and slipping.
Regular application of these substances ensures proper function of a bike's bearings by reducing friction. Graphite dust is often used as this kind of substance, as is the water displacer WD-40.

bonuses.leadin: Arrow and Pratt formulated a measure for the "absolute" type of this behavior. For 10 points each:
answers: risk aversion [or risk-averse; accept equivalents mentioning the idea of minimizing or avoiding risk or uncertainty; accept relative risk aversion; accept Arrow-Pratt measure of absolute risk aversion]
Robert Lucas [or Robert Emerson Lucas Jr.]
parts: Identify this behavior exemplified by investors who diversify their portfolios even when it lowers their expected return.
It's common to measure risk as this value with respect to the return on investment. In stats class, you can compute this value by taking the square root of the variance of a probability distribution.

This namesake of an "islands model" claimed that the cost of business cycles depended on a constant measuring risk aversion. This economist's paradox of capital flows examines the role that marginal product of capital plays in keeping nations poor.

bonuses.leadin: This dynasty's capital of Kaifeng contained a clock powered by a gigantic water wheel. For 10 points each:
answers: Song dynasty [accept Northern Song dynasty or Southern Song dynasty]
parts: Name this Chinese dynasty, whose scientists developed the earliest formula for gunpowder. Gunpowder weapons did not prevent this dynasty from losing the Battle of Yamen.
The Song dynasty polymath Shen Kuo was the first to describe the mechanism behind these devices, realizing that they pointed to magnetic north and not geographic north.
Su Song's water clock is one of the examples cited in this Sinologist's Science and Civilization in China. He names a question which asks why Asia fell behind the West in terms of scientific prowess.

bonuses.leadin: The fate of a "coma baby" is a recurring thread in a novel set during this decade whose protagonist spends a lot of time partying with ad executive Tad Allagash. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this decade in which Jay McInerey's novel Bright Lights, Big City and Bret Easton Ellis's Less Than Zero were published.
Bright Lights, Big City set off a trend for writing stories with this uncommon type of narration, also used in Italo Calvino's If on a winter's night a traveler.
Less Than Zero was written while the author was attending Bennington College, also the alma mater of this author of The Secret History and The Goldfinch.

bonuses.leadin: The 30 layers of brush strokes in this painting were applied over 14 years to its unusual lead-white wood undercoat. For 10 points each:
answers: Beeple [or Mike Winkelmann; or Michael Joseph Winkelmann]
parts: Name this painting that was stolen by nationalist Vincenzo Peruggia in the early 20th century.
Leonardo's Mona Lisa is the most visited painting at this French art museum. An expansion of this museum supervised by I. M. Pei added a glass pyramid.

In 2022, the Hermitage Museum minted an NFT from Leonardo's Madonna Litta. This other artist's NFT Everydays: the First 5000 Days sold for 66 million dollars in 2021 as part of a scam for the B20 coin.

bonuses.leadin: Unsuspecting citizens were given this substance to see if they could be brainwashed as part of the CIA's Project MKULTRA. For 10 points each:
answers: LSD [or lysergic acid diethylamide; or acid]
G. Gordon Liddy [or George Gordon Battle Liddy]
parts: Name this hallucinogen, which was central to the counterculture movements of the 1960s.

This Harvard psychologist was one of the fiercest advocates of LSD and coined the phrase "Turn On, Tune In, Drop Out." His promotion of LSD led Richard Nixon to label him "the most dangerous man in America."

This prosecutor ordered the raid on Leary's Millbrook estate, though he would later join Leary in a series of comic debates on college campuses. With E. Howard Hunt, he organized the Watergate break-in.

bonuses.leadin: The direct and indirect pathways of this system respectively are excitatory and inhibitory. For 10 points each:
parts: Give the collective name for structures including the putamen, globus pallidus, and the caudate nucleus, which among other things, control the speed of movements and action selection.
The striatum communicates to the globus pallidus and the pars reticulata using this chief inhibitory neurotransmitter.
Cell death in the substantia nigra of the basal ganglia occurs in this motor disorder that presents with a shuffling gait and a resting tremor.

bonuses.leadin: Polynices (poll-ee-NICE-eez) bribed Eriphyle (uh-RIFF-uh-lee) with this object so that Eriphyle's husband would join his alliance. For 10 points each:
answers: golden necklace of Harmonia [prompt on necklace]
Seven Against Thebes [or Hepta Epi Thebas]
parts: Name this object, depicting a two-headed serpent, which has the power to grant perpetual youth and beauty.
Polynices offered Eriphyle the necklace so that her husband would join this alliance. This group of warriors led an Argive army against a chronically-troubled city ruled by Eteocles.
Harmonia received the necklace as a gift for her wedding to this Phoenician prince, who founded Thebes and brought the alphabet to Greece.

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about Great Britain's Early Music Movement, for 10 points each:
parts: The movement gained nationwide notice with David Munrow's score for a 1971 TV series about this ruler, who is apocryphally held to be the composer of "Greensleeves."
The Early Music Shop in Bradford sells the small garklein version of this instrument. The "fiauti d'echo" parts in the fourth Brandenburg Concerto are held to have been written for this instrument.

Another Early Music pioneer, Alfred Deller, is often called the "godfather" of a rare "counter" version of this vocal type, employing it on the 1967 album Shakespeare Songs. It is the higher of the two traditional “male” voice types.

bonuses.leadin: In this novel, the writer Bergotte ("bear-GOAT") thinks "that's how I ought to have written" while examining a "little patch of yellow wall" in Vermeer's View of Delft, and then immediately dies. For 10 points each:
answers: In Search of Lost Time [or À la recherche du temps perdu, or Remembrance of Things Past; antiprompt on Swann's Way or The Prisoner or Du côté de chez Swann or La Prisonnière]
Robert de Saint-Loup ("rob-AIR duh SAN-LOOP") [accept either underlined part]
parts: Name this novel. Other artistic reflections in this novel include how "a little phrase" in Vinteuil's ("vanTUY's") sonata reminds one character of Odette de Crecy ("cressy").
In Search of Lost Time is a long, art-infused novel sequence by this French author.
The narrator of In Search of Lost Time is reminded of a Watteau portrait on seeing this aristocratic best friend of his, who marries Gilberte ("zhil-BAIR") and dies in World War One.

bonuses.leadin: The Chan master Danxia ("dan-tsee-ah") told a horrified student that he was burning a statue of the Buddha to obtain these things. For 10 points each:
answers: relics [accept more specific answers like relics of Gautama Buddha, Shakyamuni, or the Tathagata; prompt on answers like bone, ashes, or body parts of the Buddha by asking "what general type of religious object are those?"]
wisdom [or knowledge; or understanding; or insight; or gnosis]
parts: Name this general type of religious object, exemplified in Buddhism by pearl-like sarira. These objects are housed in stupas.
Some of this stuff belonging to the Buddha is enshrined under a gold-covered rock at the Kyaiktiyo (“CHIthee-oh”) Pagoda. Buddhist monks remove this bodily feature in an act called tonsuring.

An 8,000-line sutra claims to prefer this concept to a "tri·chilio·cosm" full of relics of the Buddha. The Heart Sutra summarizes a genre of Buddhist texts named for the "perfection" of this concept, or prajñā.

bonuses.leadin: A transparency that projected the words "Peace" and "Concord" onto the residence of the French ambassador following this agreement led to a riot when some poorly educated sailors thought they had been "conquered." For 10 points each:
answers: Treaty of Amiens ("AHM-yen") [or Peace of Amiens]
Joseph Bonaparte [or Joseph-Napoléon Bonaparte; or Ghjuseppe Nabulione Bonaparte; or José Napoleón Bonaparte; do not accept "Napoleon Bonaparte"]
parts: Name this 1802 treaty that secured peace between Britain and France for one year following the War of the Second Coalition.
This member of the Bonaparte family was one of the negotiators of the Treaty of Amiens. He'd later serve as both King of Naples and King of Spain.
One provision of the Treaty of Amiens called for reparations to the House of Orange, the rulers of what became this modern-day country home to The Hague.

bonuses.leadin: A tourist society named for this metal was established in 1919 in Desoto Park in Tampa, Florida. For 10 points each:
answers: tin [accept tin can tourist; accept tin lizzies]
New Jersey (Miss America was long held in Atlantic City)
parts: Identify this metal that appears before "lizzies" in a nickname for the Model T.
In the 1930s, a popular gathering spot for the Tin Can Tourists was in front of this landmark. By the time of the first automobiles, this DC obelisk no longer had an aluminum cap.

Day-campers to sites in this state were derided as being "Bennies" or "Shoobies." James V. Lafferty built Lucy the Elephant to attract tourists to Margate City in this state, a suburb of a city where the first Miss America was held.

bonuses.leadin: This model was combined with Fermi-Dirac statistics by Arnold Sommerfeld. For 10 points each:
answers: energy bands [accept valence band or conduction band or band gap]
parts: Name this model proposed by a German physicist in 1900, which uses kinetic theory to explain the motion of electrons in materials.
The Drude model gave an important theoretical explanation for this observed physical law, which states that voltage equals current times resistance.

Sommerfeld's quantum improvements to the Drude model further accounted for the observed structure of these things, including their "valence" and "conduction" types. Insulators are characterized by a large value for a quantity named for these things.

bonuses.leadin: In a thought experiment, a "radical interpreter" can't determine whether this word means "let's go hunting" or "undetached rabbit-part." For 10 points each:
parts: Give this word that is uttered by a tribesman looking at a rabbit in a thought experiment from W.V.O. Quine's Word and Object that illustrates the "inscrutability of reference."

In Word and Object, Quine likens anti-foundationalism to one of these objects named for Otto Neurath. A puzzle about identity centers on one of them named for Theseus whose timbers are slowly replaced.
The chapter on language acquisition in Word and Object was influenced by this school of psychology, whose adherents included B.F. Skinner.

bonuses.leadin: Several of this man's works were preserved in stop-motion films featuring handmade dolls by Alexander Shiryaev. For 10 points each:
answers: Marius Petipa [or Marius Ivanovich Petipa; or Victor Marius Alphonse Petipa]
parts: Name this choreographer of The Pharaoh's Daughter. He was the Principal Choreographer at St. Petersburg's Imperial Ballet from 1871 to 1903.
Petipa choreographed this ballet along with Lev Ivanov. Alexander Gorsky's updated choreography for this ballet gave all of the Sugar Plum Fairy's dances to Clara.

Petipa had earlier collaborated with Tchaikovsky on this ballet, whose third act features a wedding attended by Puss in Boots. The evil fairy Carabosse ("kah-HAH-bus") rips off the wig of Catalabutte at the christening of the title character in this ballet.

bonuses.leadin: In 1897, a barrow of waste paper was found to contain the surviving verse of a poet from this group named Thomas Traherne. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this loose group of poets that includes George Herbert. The line "thy firmness makes my circle just," which compares two lovers to the legs of a compass, exemplifies the "conceits" typical of this group.
That poem, "A Valediction: Forbidding Mourning," is by this poet whose oft-quoted lines include "no man is an island."
This Donne poem uses the conceit of comparing lovers to saints. Cleanth Brooks' The Well-Wrought Urn takes its title from this poem, which opens "For God's sake hold your tongue, and let me love."

bonuses.leadin: For 10 points each, identify the following about trade in East Africa.
parts: The regular winds caused by this weather pattern made it easy to sail from East Africa to India and back. This annual weather pattern has historically brought much rainfall to the Indian subcontinent in June and July.
Swahili speakers founded this important Indian Ocean port around 1000 CE. Fort Jesus in this secondmost-populous Kenyan city changed hands 9 times during the colonial era.

Mombasa came under the control of the Sultanate of this modern-day country in 1698. In 1971, the British helped oust the reactionary Sultan Said bin Taimur (“sigh-EED bin tah-MORE”) from this country in favor of his son, Qaboos ("caboose").

bonuses.leadin: The next large strategic mission after the James Webb is an infrared telescope named for this person. For 10 points each:
answers: Nancy Grace Roman [accept Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope]
Harvard University [accept the Harvard stellar classification or Harvard Computers]
parts: Name this first Chief of Astronomy at NASA whose work with the Orbiting Astronomical Observatories led directly to the Hubble.

Roman's graduate studies took her to the Yerkes ("YUR-keez") Observatory, which has a less-popular alternative to this school's widely-used stellar classification system. Annie Jump Cannon and Henrietta Leavitt made observations as part of this American university's "computers".
Leavitt discovered the relationship between the period of a Cepheid ("SEF-e-id") variable and this quantity. This quantity for a star is the total amount of energy it outputs.

bonuses.leadin: An essay by this author describes how she uses "all the Englishes I grew up with" in her writing. For 10 points each:
answers: fortune cookie factories [accept any answers involving places that make fortune cookies; prompt on partial answers like food factories or cookie factories or factories]
parts: Name this author, who described being forced to pretend to be her mother in the essay "Mother Tongue." Her breakthrough novel describes four women who play a traditional game together at a Baptist Church in San Francisco.
This aforementioned Amy Tan novel includes characters such as the chess prodigy Waverly Jong, whose mother plays mahjong ("MAH-zhong") as part of the title group.
In a section from the final part of The Joy Luck Club, Lindo Jong and An-Mei Hsu get a job working at one of these locations before concluding that they produce "bad instruction."
